Who was Kevin Carter?

Roberto Baldizon
Mar 23

In this article, we’ll discuss famous photographer Kevin Carter, whose work had a significant impact on South Africa’s, India’s, and Sudan’s civil rights movements that raised issues on a global scale regarding inhuman behavior towards minorities in these regions of the world. Carter was Born in apartheid South Africa on September 13, 1960. After High School, he dropped his studies to become a pharmacist, but he drafted into the army.
Carter decided he wanted to become a news photographer after witnessing the Church Street bombing in Pretoria in 1983. In 1984 he started working with the Johannesburg Star, shooting pictures which exposed the brutality of the apartheid.

Some of his work is included in the following images which he took as a journalist photographer with a social consciousness orientation to raise awareness of humanitarian issues throughout the Commonwealth.

“I was appalled at what they were doing. I was appalled at what I was doing. But then people started talking about those pictures then I felt that maybe my actions hadn’t been at all bad. Being a witness to something this horrible wasn’t necessarily such a bad thing to
do.” -Kevin Carter
“I am depressed without phone money for rent money for child support .money for debts money! I am haunted by the vivid memories of killings and corpses and anger and pain of starving or wounded children, of trigger-happy madmen, often police, of killer executioners I have gone to join Ken [a recently deceased colleague, Ken Oosterbroek] if I am that lucky.” -Kevin Carter

On July 27, 1994, Kevin Carter took his life by taping one end of a hose to his pickup’s truck exhaust pipe and running the other end to the passenger-side window.
